cards.html:
Friends,

Welcome to Election Insider, a Lever feature exclusive for our supporting subscribers to give you the necessary information you will not get from corporate media heading into the midterms this November. Each Election Insider is designed to cut through all the noise of the election and give you succinct facts about what’s actually going on — from who is funding the candidates, to which races could most impact specific policies.

Before we dive in:

  • JOIN US: You get to ask Rep. Ro Khanna your questions at our next Lever Live event TONIGHT at 7PM ET. We’ll discuss whether he and House Dems will block Joe Manchin’s pipeline bill. Click here to find the show.
  • WATCH THIS: Check out our new video, where we expose the big paydays of hospital CEOs who denied striking nurses better pay and benefits — then hit the red button to subscribe to our YouTube channel!
  • SPREAD THE WORD: Share this article on Twitter and Facebook, and forward this email to encourage others to subscribe to The Lever.

Rock the boat,

Sirota

cards.html:
Help us spread the word! Please forward this email to family and friends.

Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up for free to receive original reporting like this in your inbox every day.

sections: As we rapidly approach the country’s November midterm elections, corporate media seems uninterested in one of the biggest threats to democracy: Billionaires and Big Business using huge sums of money to try to secretly buy elections on both sides of the aisle.
Increasingly, a small handful of donors hold outsized influence in American elections, thanks in large part to the Supreme Court’s 2010 ruling in
Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission,
which gave wealthy donors and special interest groups license to spend unlimited cash on elections. This year is no exception.
We know little to nothing about some of the biggest donors this cycle — and that is by design. These political advocacy nonprofits, as

, are 501(c)(4) social welfare organizations, named after the corresponding tax code section that deems them tax-exempt. More commonly, they are known as dark money groups, because they are not required to publicly disclose their donors.
In this first edition of Election Insider, we break down the biggest spenders in the 2022 election cycle, from dark money groups to billionaire chief executives.
So far in the 2021-2022 midterm election cycle,

have been funneled from dark money groups and other interests into super PACs, which can spend unlimited sums of money to influence elections. Republican super PAC donations have so far totaled $865 million, while donations to Democratic super PACs have hit $2.7 billion. Below, we highlight the top donors fueling each party, according to data from Political MoneyLine.
TOP FIVE 2022 CYCLE DONORS TO REPUBLICAN SUPER PACS:
, founders of shipping supply giant Uline, have donated

to conservative outside groups. The donor couple has spent big money over the last several years funding the GOP in Wisconsin and nationwide, going so far as to feed the coffers of the most extreme right-members of Congress, including QAnon conspiracy theory supporter
, founder and head of Chicago-based hedge fund behemoth Citadel, along with his ex-wife
to Republican groups. In total, hedge funds have spent more than
on federal candidates during the current cycle, according to OpenSecrets. This part of the finance industry has an interest in policy decisions on tax issues like the
, which allows private equity and some hedge fund managers to enjoy much lower taxes on some of their income.
, the House GOP’s dark money arm that does not disclose its donors, has donated
. Most of that money has gone to its sister super PAC, the Congressional Leadership Fund, which recently launched a
slamming President Joe Biden for his decision to cancel some student loan debt.
, the dark money group affiliated with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) that helped

alone on trying to crush Sen. Raphael Warnock’s (D-Ga.) chances of keeping his seat this November. The
One Nation as “the primary source of outside air cover for Senate Republicans.”
, mega-wealthy founder of Wall Street trading giant Susquehanna International Group who is notorious for sketchy
and his championing of school privatization, has donated

, since the passage of former President Donald Trump’s 2017 law that massively cut taxes for the rich, Yass has backed several pro-Trump candidates. (Billionaire venture capitalist Peter Thiel, longtime friend of Ohio Senate GOP candidate
, has also donated $30 million to Republican groups.)
TOP FIVE 2022 CYCLE DONORS TO DEMOCRATIC SUPER PACS:
, billionaire hedge fund tycoon and long-time Democratic megadonor, tops the list with a whopping $127 million in political contributions so far this election season.

made billions launching the cryptocurrency exchange platform FTX, and while the 30-year-old entrepreneur has pledged to use his fortune to promote the concept of “effective altruism,” much of the $35 million he’s spent this cycle could encourage his politician recipients to shield crypto from increased regulation, even as crypto has proven to be highly speculative, worsening inequality and the climate crisis alike. Bankman-Fried poured $4 million into the Anthony Scaramucci-backed GMI PAC, focused on supporting crypto-friendly candidates. He also used $27 million to almost wholly fund the “pandemic prevention” super PAC Protect Our Future, which appears to have done more to support Bankman-Fried’s favored candidates than it has to address specific pandemic risks.

Bankman-Fried’s bankrolling of establishment candidates could be hurting progressives. He contributed more than $1 million to help corporate-backed Shontel Brown defeat progressive Nina Turner in the Democratic primary for Ohio’s 11th congressional district, and spent more than $11 million trying — and failing — to stop progressive Oregon state Rep. Andrea Salinas from winning the Democratic primary in the state’s 6th congressional district. He also shelled out a quarter million to the pro-Israel Democratic Majority for Israel (DMFI) PAC that has spent millions to crush progressives this year, and has donated $1.4 million to the Republican-aligned America United PAC and the Alabama Conservatives Fund.
, a Democratic Party-aligned dark money group affiliated with Senate Majority PAC, has donated $28 million to groups boosting Senate Democratic candidates, as well as promoting voter turnout.
, a dark money group founded and funded by Soros that focuses on supporting criminal justice reform and election administration policy efforts, has donated $25 million to another Soros-backed group.

, the group charged with supporting the party’s gubernatorial candidates, has poured $23 million into this year’s races. The organization is particularly focused on beating back Republicans in states where abortion access is endangered in light of the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

Most of the donors listed above have given to super PACs. These efforts have turned these operations into political juggernauts, with the power to drastically shape elections and in turn, federal and state policy outcomes

The following political organizations are some of the biggest donation recipients to date for the 2022 midterms and boast noteworthy top donors, according to data from OpenSecrets and Political MoneyLine.
, a Democratic super PAC that boosts Senate campaigns, has brought in

. Majority Forward, the Democratic Senate’s dark money arm, has supplied $27.3 million of that amount. Other top donors include Chicago-based Newsweb Corporation founder and billionaire Fred Eychaner, who has donated $8 million, as well as the Greater New York Hospital Association, which

former Democratic New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s campaign coffers before he signed legislation shielding hospital and nursing-home executives from the threat of COVID-related lawsuits. Renaissance Technologies hedge fund founder and billionaire James Simon, and Indiana-based Deborah Simon of
, which seeks to retain a Democratic House Majority, has raised
, with billionaires Eychaner, Bankman-Fried, and Simon collectively contributing $17.5 million to the organization. In addition,

, a dark money group launched in 2019 and is affiliated with House Majority PAC, has contributed $4 million. George Marcus, chairman of the massive real estate brokerage Marcus & Millichap and the real estate investment trust Essex Property Trust, has also spent big this cycle with a $2 million donation —
came in just before Democrats let the pandemic eviction moratorium lapse.
so far. The top donor, with a $3 million contribution, is Sedona Magnet LLC, a company registered in Nevada whose sole officer is
Budget Suites of America and hundreds of real estate properties and developments. Bigelow is also an

, having pressed former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) to initiate a government study of UFOs. Other notable donors include the Seminole Tribe of Florida, which also gave $3 million, likely to protect its

with the state of Florida, and health care giant Centene Corporation, which donated nearly $1.5 million and stands to benefit from potential new Medicaid contracts and state tax incentives. Stockbroker giant Ameritrade founder Joe Ricketts and his wife Marlene, and Home Depot co-founder Bernard Marcus and his wife Wilma, have also donated significant sums.
, which has brought in a whopping

is among the biggest donors in key gubernatorial races this year. It’s a perfect example of how these types of groups funnel money back and forth to serve a broader partisan agenda. Illinois Democratic Governor J.B. Pritzker tops the list of the association’s supporters, with a donation of $24 million. As

, Pritzker and his administration have still not passed an assault weapons ban, despite his rhetoric suggesting interest in doing so. His family hotel chain, Hyatt Hotels, has hosted NRA events for years, including one this May. Dark money group
is another big-ticket donor, having contributed $6.5 million this cycle.
, which focuses on securing Democratic majorities in statehouses nationwide,

, with dark money group Emerging American Majorities — which is interested in improving diversity in state legislatures — having contributed upwards of $600,000. Tobacco giant Altria Group has donated a similar amount, since the company is a huge investor in e-cigarette giant Juul, which has been subject to growing scrutiny from state and federal lawmakers. Other top donors include major unions representing workers in the public sector, telecommunications industry, and electrical industry.
, the Republican counterpart to the DLCC, has received

in political contributions. Corporate lobbying behemoth U.S. Chamber of Commerce and its affiliates have donated more than $1.5 million to protect business interests at state capitols, while tobacco companies Altria and British American Tobacco have together given $1.6 million.
, the powerful right-wing dark money group led by anti-abortion activist Leonard Leo, has donated $1.1 million. And oil and gas giant Chevron, which
from the recently passed Inflation Reduction Act thanks to
Sen. Joe Manchin (W.Va.) conceding to his industry donors’ demands, donated $778,000.
All in all, there’s a lot to keep an eye out for in the midterms in the coming weeks — and
will be here to supply you with everything you need to know as these key elections unfold.
